clinical_study.brief_title: Core Body Temperature Measurement During Hot and Cold Environmental Exposure
clinical_study.official_title: Tympanic and Frontal Versus Oesophageal Core Temperature Reading During Hot and Cold Environmental Exposure

brief_summary.textblock: Accurate measurement of core body temperature at the scene of an accident is critical for both diagnosis and treatment/triage decisions for hypothermic patients. Measurement in the lower third of the oesophagus is considered the gold standard of CT reading, but invasive and hardly applicable with a conscious patient. Tympanic membrane sensors for CT reading have been widely tested by may be unreliable in extreme environmental temperatures. Similarly, the Double Sensor device is a non-invasive device and is promising for prehospital use but has not been sufficiently verified under very cold and hot environmental conditions. Furthermore, comparisons of different non-invasive methods with oesophageal measurement in extreme conditions are lacking. The objective of these studies is to compare different techniques of core body temperature measurement with exposure to cold and hot environments.

primary_outcome.measure: Difference between oesophageal and epitympanic temperature
primary_outcome.time_frame: 10 min measurment at +20 °C followed by 10 min measurment at -20 °C

arm_group.description: temperature is measured in cold (-20°C) environment first, and warm (23°C) environment afterwards
temperature is measured in warm (23°C) environment first, and cold (-20°C) environment afterwards

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- >18 years old
- ASA class 1
Exclusion Criteria:
- <18 years old
- American society of anesthesiologists class >1
- history of ear, nose, throat surgery
- congenital malformation of head/throat/ear/nose
- absence of informed consent
